title: Pro Log: Fred Wright and Pfeiffer Georgi win British National Road Races, Mark Renshaw joins Astana to aid Mark Cavendish, Ben Healy extends contract with EF Education-EasyPost and teams announce Grand Tour line-ups
content:
Cyclist
Pro Log: Fred Wright and Pfeiffer Georgi win British National Road Races, Mark Renshaw joins Astana to aid Mark Cavendish, Ben Healy extends contract with EF Education-EasyPost and teams announce Grand Tour line-ups

Welcome back to another edition of Pro Log. An extremely busy National Championships week has concluded with road race, time-trial and circuit race titles won worldwide. We‚Äôll get into all of those in a second.

In terms of racing, the women‚Äôs Giro Donne and men‚Äôs Tour de France begin this week; time just creeps up on us, doesn‚Äôt it? Check out our pro racing hub page to stay up to date.

Related Posts

Giro d‚ÄôItalia Rest Day Recap: Tao Geoghegan Hart breaks hip, flooding hits Italy, weather shortens stage and Ben Healy is a phenomenon

Giro Donne 2023: Route, how to watch and everything you need to know

Men‚Äôs Tour de France 2023: Stage-by-stage preview and everything you need to know

1. National Championships week: All the winners

This past week National Championships jerseys were retained, relinquished and reassigned across the globe. A full list of winners ‚Äì of which there are hundreds ‚Äì can be found via First Cycling. Let‚Äôs hope the teams do justice when incorporating flags into their kit. Go big or go home. I‚Äôm looking at you, UAE Team Emirates.

Big names such as Remco Evenepoel (Belgium), Ben Healy (Ireland), Dylan van Baarle (Netherlands) and Tadej Pogaƒçar (Slovenia) won their respective men‚Äôs road races and Liane Lippert (Germany), Demi Vollering (Netherlands), Lotte Kopecky (Belgium) and Marlen Reusser (Switzerland) beat the field in their respective women‚Äôs road races.

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

Results powered by FirstCycling.com

The races in Great Britain were held in Redcar and Cleveland in North Yorkshire, England. Josh Charlton and Maddie Leech won the U23 time-trials, while Josh Tarling and Lizzie Holden won the elite TTs. Sam Watson and Anna Shackley won the U23 road race titles. Megan Barker and Ollie Wood were victorious in the circuit races before Pfeiffer Georgi won her second national road race title in an uphill sprint finish and Fred Wright broke away from a trio to take a solo victory in the men‚Äôs road race. As he crossed the line, Wright pointed to the sky in honour of his Bahrain Victorious teammate Gino M√§der, who sadly died at the Tour de Suisse this month.

2. Mark Renshaw joins Astana Qazaqstan‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ Just not as a rider. Mark Renshaw, one of the greatest leadout men in cycling history, who played a part in helping Mark Cavendish secure many victories across his career, joins Astana as a sprint and leadout consultant.

Astana are not a team known for their leadout capabilities. Cavendish was seen on the wheel of Geraint Thomas (Ineos Grenadiers) on the final stage of the 2023 Giro d‚ÄôItalia, which led to his first successful sprint of the race. A fond memory indeed.

It‚Äôs hoped Renshaw can help Cavendish once more, albeit not within the peloton, to win at the Tour de France. At the moment, he is currently tied for the all-time record with Eddy Merckx on 34 stage victories.

3. Ben Healy extends contract with EF Education-EasyPost

Newly-crowned Irish Road Race Champion Ben Healy has signed a new multi-year contract with EF Education-EasyPost just a year and a half into his tenure with the squad.

22-year-old Healy has been a phenomenon in 2023 in the Ardennes Classics and at the Giro d‚ÄôItalia with his explosive attacks, determined breakaways and victory on Stage 8 of the Giro, and he seems to be thriving in the team. We‚Äôll no doubt see him lighting up races for years to come, and he looks likely to also take on more of a leadership role.

Healy said the team gives ‚Äòa lot of opportunities to race the way that I want to race‚Äô.

4. Ineos Grenadiers, Lidl-Trek, Jumbo-Visma announce Grand Tour teams

To celebrate 25 years of @INEOS, we called on the INEOS sporting family to help announce our exciting #TDF2023 lineup

Meet our team pic.twitter.com/PNvzCSzt74

‚Äî INEOS Grenadiers (@INEOSGrenadiers) June 26, 2023

Teams have been getting more creative with line-ups in recent years. Ineos Grenadiers got Eliud Kipchoge, Lewis Hamilton, George Russell and Toto Wolff and more to announce some of their riders for the upcoming Tour de France, the two connected by sponsorship from petrochemical giant Ineos.

Don‚Äôt forget your receipt!

We‚Äôre taking some excellent international produce @LeTour and @giro_donne pic.twitter.com/AycdGVQuim

‚Äî Lidl-Trek (@TrekSegafredo) June 26, 2023

The team formerly known as Trek-Segafredo typically beat all others when it comes to the announcements. Now called Lidl-Trek, they revealed their line-ups for the Tour de France and Giro Donne in the form of a Lidl receipt. The riders are ‚Äòpriced‚Äô based on their number of participations in the race. Elisa Longo Borghini is the most expensive for the women at 11.00 and Tony Gallopin for the men at 10.00. Elynor B√§ckstedt, Shirin van Anrooij, Juan Pedro L√≥pez and Mattias Skejlmose are all thrown in for free.

Now that sounds like a good deal. Rumour has it Bauke Mollema got lost in a middle aisle somewhere.

Ready to ride their dreams.

Here‚Äôs the Jumbo-Visma‚Äôs team to help with Jonas Vingegaard‚Äôs yellow jersey defence. At least it‚Äôs not a creepy AI this year.

And their main rivals‚Ä¶

Is this the face of the 2023 Tour de France winner? We‚Äôll find out soon. See you next week.
